event.title: <show-title>Beetlejuice</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Haunt along with the ghost with the most, babes
event.description: Un-live all the undead fun with spooky props galore and all kinds of delights for the Recently Deceased. BEETLEJUICE is the timeless tale of a ghostly couple and the troublesome “bio-exorcist” they employ to help scare away the living inhabiting their house. It’s megawatt Michael Keaton at his kookiest, Winona Ryder, Alec Baldwin, and Geena Davis at their dreamiest, and vintage Tim Burton from start to finish. This ghoulishly interactive screening comes with Miss Argentina sashes, shrimp keychains, BEETLEJUICE stickers, and even sticky eyeballs. Btw, if you feel an uncontrollable urge to Day-o (the banana song), that’s normal.

contentBlocks.paragraphs: Un-live all the undead fun with spooky props galore and all kinds of delights for the Recently Deceased. show.title: The Lost Boys

event.title: <show-title>The Lost Boys</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Vamp out with THE LOST BOYS
event.description:
When you say "defining piece of '80s pop culture," we say "Movie Party."

Whether you’re a blood-sucking “el vampiro” or the meanest, baddest monster-basher in town, everyone’s invited to a night of ’80s vampires, interactive props, and excessive beach saxophone at THE LOST BOYS Movie Party. It's only noodles, Michael...or gummy worms. Also some plastic vampire teeth, holy water, and garlic all gathered in your take-out box.

So don’t sit around at home reading the TV Guide. Join us for a fun night celebrating one of the most entertaining pieces of ’80s pop culture ever made.

contentBlocks.paragraphs: When you say "defining piece of '80s pop culture," we say "Movie Party."

show.title: Dial Code Santa Claus
show.headline: Welcome to your new favorite holiday slayride

landscapeHeroImage.altText: Hero Image Dial Code Santa Claus

portraitHeroImage.altText: Hero Image Dial Code Santa Claus

event.title: <show-title>Dial Code Santa Claus</show-title>
event.headline: Your new favorite holiday slayride.
event.description:
Previously only available via VHS bootlegs, DIAL CODE SANTA CLAUS (aka DEADLY GAMES) is your new favorite holiday slayride. Thomas is a typical 1980s kid: he loves computers, role-playing games, and his dog. While Mom is away at the office on Christmas Eve, Thomas and his grandfather are left home alone—perfect timing for a disgruntled, bloodthirsty mall Santa Claus to climb down the chimney and terrorize the house. But Hell hath no fury like a mulleted ten-year-old with an arsenal of toys! Shot a year before HOME ALONE, the French-made DIAL CODE SANTA CLAUS has almost the same plot—only filled with more style, bloodshed, and Rambo references.

Screening a restored 35mm print.

landscapeHeroImage.altText: scene from Dial Code Santa Claus

portraitHeroImage.altText: scene from Dial Code Santa Claus

posterImage.altText: Dial Code Santa Claus movie poster

eventType.title: Special Event
eventType.headline: For Movie Lovers, by Movie Lovers
eventType.description: Whether it’s a movie-inspired feast, an interactive party, or a screening paired with a live performance, we love sharing the movies we love in new and exciting ways.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Scream (1996)
show.headline: "Do you like scary movies?"

event.title: <show-title>Scream (1996)</show-title>
event.headline: “Do you like scary movies?”
event.description: In 1996, the once innocuous question became synonymous with terror with the release of Wes Craven’s SCREAM. Based on an original script penned by struggling *homosexual* screenwriter Kevin Williamson simply titled “Scary Movie,” SCREAM became a surprise hit earning $173 million worldwide, a record for slasher films. SCREAM’s concept was deceptively simple: beautiful teenagers in a small northern California town receive menacing phone calls from a stranger before being killed by a man in a ghostly mask. Williamson’s script complicated the concept by including references to the classic slasher films of the '70s and '80s and self-aware characters who were well-versed in the plot points and cliches of the horror film genre. The meta-slasher film was born. AND IT’S SUPER QUEER. Featuring dialogue that only a gay person would write, SCREAM is quotable out the wazoo and it’s so damn sassy. “She has her own bubble butt boyfriend, Billy,” is a line in this film, folks. And don’t get us started about the sexual tension between Billy Loomis (Skeet Ulrich) and Stu Macher (Matthew Lillard) – those are two men who have had sex together, damnit. Sidney (Neve Campbell), Tatum (Rose McGowen), and GALE FUCKING WEATHERS (Courtney Cox) have all become queer feminist icons and for good reason – they exude power and poise in a way few horror film heroines are afforded the opportunity to. And Sweet Deputy Dewey (David Arquette), the bumbling himbo of our dreams, how could you not fall deep in gay love with such an earnest and goofy character? SCREAM is a perfect film and one of the queerest slasher films ever, and its legacy includes five very queer sequels and more to come. Don’t miss your chance to catch this horror classic on the big screen. Don’t fuck with the original, y’all.

show.title: Drag Me to Hell
show.headline: Even nice people can go to hell

event.title: <show-title>Drag Me to Hell</show-title>
event.headline: Even nice people can go to hell
event.description: Christine Brown is a loan officer at a bank but is worried about her lot in life. She's in competition with a competent colleague for an assistant manager position and isn't too sure about her status with her boyfriend. Worried that her boss will think less of her if she shows weakness, she refuses a time extension on a loan to an old woman, Mrs. Ganush, who now faces foreclosure and the loss of her house. In retaliation, the old woman places a curse on her which, she subsequently learns, will result in her being taken to hell in a few days time. With the help of a psychic, she tries to rid herself of the demon, but faces several hurdles in the attempt.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Halloween III: Season of the Witch
show.headline: Happy, happy Halloween, Silver Shamrock!

event.title: <show-title>Halloween III: Season of the Witch</show-title>
event.headline: The night no one comes home!
event.description:
John Carpenter and Debra Hill are back! But they didn’t bring Michael Myers with them! And that’s why no one liked this movie when it was released in 1982. Their loss! Tom “NIGHT OF THE CREEPS” Atkins stars as a bad dad on the trail of a string of brutal murders that might be connected to a Halloween mask-maker...and a small town’s sinister secrets. The first (and last) step toward turning the HALLOWEEN franchise into a series of unconnected movies that take place on Halloween, Carpenter and Hill deliver an incredible nerve-shredder that’s more in line with a late '80s Stephen King novel than HALLOWEEN. And that’s a great thing for us, especially considering that HALLOWEEN III features one of Carpenter and co-writer Alan Howarth’s most life-affirming synthesizer scores.

Warning: This movie will be played loud. (Joseph A. Ziemba)

show.title: [REC]
show.headline: Ground zero for found footage magnificence.

event.title: <show-title>[REC]</show-title>
event.headline: Ground zero for found footage magnificence.
event.description: Angela (Manuela Velasco) and her colleague Pablo are shooting an episode of their documentary TV show with firefighters in Barcelona. But when the crew responds to a 9-1-1 call involving a berserk woman who is trapped in an apartment building, things get wild. [REC] is like THE BLAIR WITCH PROJECT on steroids, an 80-minute found footage explosion of Romero-esque dread and Cronenberg-style body horror. Anchored by a powerful performance from Velasco, this is what happens when intelligent design, gross-out gore, and a deep love for genre history join together for the betterment of humankind.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Silent Night, Deadly Night Part 2
show.headline: The nightmare is about to begin...again!

event.title: <show-title>Silent Night, Deadly Night Part 2</show-title>
event.headline: The nightmare is about to begin...again!
event.description:
Every day is "Garbage Day!" Ricky – the traumatized brother of the psychopathic Billy from SILENT NIGHT, DEADLY NIGHT – has been released from the mental hospital. But before he can start life anew, Ricky must destroy Mother Superior, the powerful nun who caused his brother's violent demise. Be it by knife, umbrella, or car battery, Ricky unleashes a bloodbath of carnage on unsuspecting victims as he makes his way to Mother Superior's home on Christmas – Santa suit in tow. Making clever use of recycled footage from its predecessor and featuring an unhinged performance by star Eric Freeman, SILENT NIGHT, DEADLY NIGHT PART 2 is an unforgettable yuletide horror experience.

DCP courtesy of the American Genre Film Archive

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Tales from the Hood
show.headline: Rusty Cundieff’s essential anthology

event.title: <show-title>Tales from the Hood</show-title>
event.headline: Rusty Cundieff’s essential anthology.
event.description:
There will never be another horror anthology as powerful as TALES FROM THE HOOD. Written and directed by Rusty Cundieff (FEAR OF A BLACK HAT) and executive produced by Spike Lee, this four-story anthology explores the terrors of racism, police brutality, and generational angst – all told from a Black perspective, and with help from acid-soaked effects by Screaming Mad George (A NIGHTMARE ON ELM STREET 3). Subversive, cathartic, and more relevant than ever, TALES FROM THE HOOD is essential ‘90s studio horror that paved the way for everything from GET OUT to Lovecraft Country.

Screening the 4K restoration

Content Warning: This film contains sequences of flashing lights, a brief scene featuring real-life crime photos, and scenes of domestic abuse.

show.title: The Changeling (1980)
show.headline: George C. Scott is haunted by ghosts and grief

event.title: <show-title>The Changeling (1980)</show-title>
event.headline: George C. Scott is haunted by ghosts and grief
event.description:
In partnership with Severin Films, AGFA presents the fully-restored 1980 gem that made Martin Scorsese's 11 Scariest Horror Movies Of All Time list. This movie represents a career peak for both star George C. Scott and director Peter Medak (THE RULING CLASS.) Oscar-winner Scott delivers major feels as a classical music composer consumed by grief after his wife and daughter are killed in a shocking accident. When he moves to a secluded Victorian mansion, he finds himself haunted by a paranormal entity that unleashes an even more disturbing secret. Based on actual events!

Restoration via Severin Films; DCP courtesy of the American Genre Film Archive

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre Part 2
show.headline: An explosion of 1980s excess

landscapeHeroImage.altText: Texas chain saw massacre 1974 sp hero2

event.title: <show-title>The Texas Chainsaw Massacre Part 2</show-title>
event.headline: An explosion of 1980s excess
event.description:
Exploding with day-glo visuals and over-the-top gallows humor, THE TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE 2 is not what audiences expected from recovering wunderkind Tobe Hooper in 1986. But that’s exactly what makes it so special. Using the surreal terror of the first movie as a jumping off point, TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE 2 plays out like a deranged form of vaudeville with Leatherface as a sexually frustrated straight-man. Featuring electric performances from Bill “Chop Top” Moseley, Caroline Williams, and a chainsaw-wielding Dennis Hopper, it’s time to praise this movie for what it is—a drop-dead masterpiece of subversive 1980s horror.

Screening from an archival 35mm print.

show.title: The Mummy (1932) + The Wolf Man (1941) Double Feature
show.headline: Unwrap this snarling Universal Monsters duo

show.title: Bill & Ted's Bogus Journey
show.headline: Once...they made history. Now...they are history.

landscapeHeroImage.altText: Bill and teds bogus journey hero

portraitHeroImage.altText: Bill and teds bogus journey hero

event.title: <show-title>Bill & Ted's Bogus Journey</show-title>
event.headline: Once...they made history. Now...they are history.
event.description: After a time travel-aided history presentation created Bill S. Preston, Esq. and Ted Theodore Logan's sonic utopia, everything should've been fine, right? Would-be despot De Nomolos has another idea: send a pair of evil doppelganger robots to kill our heroic duo before they can win their battle of the bands! A wyld adventure that astral projects our head-banging heroes through Heaven & Hell, BOGUS JOURNEY stands as one of the rare sequels that equals (and to some, surpasses) the original. STATION!

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Breathless (1983)
show.headline: He's the last man on earth any woman needs... and every woman wants.

event.title: <show-title>Breathless (1983)</show-title>
event.headline: He's the last man on Earth any woman needs... and every woman wants.
event.description:
Jesse (a very hot Richard Gere) is obsessed with Jerry Lee Lewis, the Silver Surfer, and Monica (Valérie Kaprisky, equally hot), the French UCLA undergrad with whom he had a fling in Vegas. On his way to see her, Jesse shoots a cop at a traffic stop. Now, his mug is plastered all over town as a cop killer, which is really going to mess with his chances with Monica. After pioneering faux-documentary with DAVID HOLZMAN'S DIARY, cinematic heroes L.M. Kit Carson and Jim McBride reteamed to remake the opening salvo of the French New Wave, Jean Luc Godard's BREATHLESS. JLG's original film was a shocking provocation that, by 1983, had codified into a canonical classic. McBride and Carson's film is slippery, dangerously electric masterpiece the world still hasn't caught up with.

35mm print courtesy of Park Circus.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Delicatessen
show.headline: Go in with a job, come out a sausage

event.title: <show-title>Delicatessen</show-title>
event.headline: Go in with a job, come out a sausage
event.description:
In a post-apocalyptic country where food is hard to come by and grain has the same lure as cash, an unemployed circus clown applies to work as a maintenance man in a dilapidated apartment building, not knowing the landlord is butchering his employees to feed his tenants! However, his charming demeanor causes a rift among the residents and threatens the whole meat-making operation, especially when he falls in love with the landlord’s daughter.

From the directing talents of Marc Caro and Jean-Pierre Jeunet and starring the wonderful, unique talents of Dominique Pinon (DIVA, AMELIE), DELICATESSEN is a wild original of cannibals, vegetarian troglodytes, and an imaginative setting that only the director of AMELIE and THE CITY OF LOST CHILDREN can provide. (Jazmyne Moreno)

4k DCP courtesy of Rialto Pictures

show.title: Eega
show.headline: A murdered man is reincarnated as a housefly and seeks to avenge his death

event.title: <show-title>Eega</show-title>
event.headline: Rated RRR for Reincarnation Revenge Rampage
event.description: Director SS Rajamouli is a visionary artist with a string of major blockbusters under his belt, including last year’s Academy Award-winning big-screen phenomenon RRR, but there’s nothing quite like EEGA. This is the film that introduced him to the world. Somewhere between DIE HARD, THE FAST AND THE FURIOUS, FINAL DESTINATION, and GHOST is EEGA. With the black-and-white morality of an old Western, Rajamouli shows us that love really does conquer all, for all creatures, great and small. (Josh Hurtado)

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Mute Witness
show.headline: The most underrated wintry thriller of the 1990s

event.title: <show-title>Mute Witness</show-title>
event.headline: The most underrated wintry thriller of the 1990s
event.description:
The first international production shot in Moscow following the fall of the Soviet Union, MUTE WITNESS finds Billy, a non-verbal special effects artist, coming across an after-hours snuff film shoot. Marrying De Palma-esque maximalism with a cat-and-mouse thriller, fact and fiction collide in one of the most undersung genre works of the 1990s. Featuring a barely ambulatory Alec Guinness as a Russian gangster!

Get in on the ground floor of the cult before the end of the year. (Jake Isgar)

DCP courtesy of the American Genre Film Archive via Arrow Video

show.title: Shredder Orpheus
show.headline: What if Jean Cocteau knew how to grind a half-pipe?

event.title: <show-title>Shredder Orpheus</show-title>
event.headline: What if Jean Cocteau knew how to grind a half-pipe?
event.description:
“They’re shredding their way to Hell!”

The Greek myth gets reworked as a post-apocalyptic skateboard rock opera in this nightmarishly shredding, ultra-big hair, inspirationally low-budget hallucination. Rockstar Orpheus (Robert McGinley) descends into the underworld armed with a skateboard and a futuristic guitar to save the world from mind-controlling television signals.

show.title: The Dragon Lives Again
show.headline: Not even death can stop Bruce Lee!

posterImages.altText: THE DRAGON LIVES AGAIN sp poster

event.title: <show-title>The Dragon Lives Again</show-title>
event.headline: Not even death can stop Bruce Lee!
event.description: Bruce Lee is dead! Long live Bruce Lee! Not even slightly inconvenienced by the lack of an actual living Bruce Lee, opportunistic producers unleashed a tidal wave of Brucesploitation movies starring martial artists with names like Bruce Li, Bruce Le, and Bruce Leong. As the trend reached peak saturation, the gimmicks got weirder: Bruce Lee vs. Supermen, Bruce Lee vs. the Clones of Bruce Lee, Bruce Lee vs. Gay Power! None of them are as weird, however, as THE DRAGON LIVES AGAIN, which begins where Bruce's life ended. The now-dead Lee finds himself in the underworld, where after incurring the wrath of the King of the Underworld, he meets Popeye the Sailor Man at a bar. Sound weird yet? A coalition of criminals led by "The Exorcist" and including such illustrious members as James Bond, Clint Eastwood, "The Godfather," Emmannuelle, and Dracula begin plotting against the King and attempting to kill Bruce. This is zany, out-of-control genre filmmaking at its best. Expect wacky slapstick, weird sex jokes, and genuine kung fu fighting set to music stolen from other soundtracks.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: To Die For
show.headline: Kidman shines in tabloid trash turned high art

event.title: <show-title>To Die For</show-title>
event.headline: Kidman shines in tabloid trash turned high art
event.description: Gus Van Sant turns tabloid trash to quick-witted high art in this ripped-from-the-headlines tale of a TV reporter (Nicole Kidman) and the two boneheaded teens (baby-faced Casey Affleck and Joaquin Phoenix) she hires to kill her husband. One of the seminal Nicole Kidman performances, TO DIE FOR cemented her status as one of the rising stars of her era and set the stage for a long-spanning career full of fearless transformations.

show.title: The Rocky Horror Picture Show
show.headline: Do the time warp with us, again

landscapeHeroImage.altText: A53 EGF0 Nz HRG Ku R Itsrt XBM8 FCD

portraitHeroImage.altText: THE ROCKY HORROR PICTURE SHOW portrait

event.title: <show-title>The Rocky Horror Picture Show</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Don’t dream it, be it…at our ROCKY HORROR Movie Party
event.description:
Now, at long last, the antici.....pation is over! As the cult of ROCKY HORROR nears its fifth decade, Alamo Drafthouse's celebration of this pioneer of interactive movies has incorporated new breakthroughs, elusive ingredients, and that... SPARK which will make the RHPS experience better than ever!

Now, we know that some ROCKY HORROR screenings can become a little too focused on yelling out those callbacks, so our hosts will make sure we strike a good balance between having some interactive fun while also allowing everyone to enjoy the movie on its own terms.

But we also know that the key to the perfect ROCKY HORROR screening is to have fun and live the movie. With thrilling props, the most outrageous callbacks, boisterous sing-alongs, and stimulating pre-show games, our Movie Party will be your ultimate ROCKY HORROR PICTURE SHOW – whether this is your first or 500th viewing.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

marketStrings.value: The personal closed captioning device displays feature film dialogue and other audio in the form of English-language text for individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing.

The descriptive audio headset provides individuals who are blind or have low vision with an English-language narration of the details of the feature presentation that can't be understood by the soundtrack alone.

Upon request at the box office, we provide assistive listening headsets with amplified audio for those individuals who are hard of hearing. For guests who prefer to use their own hearing aids, neck loops, or cochlear implants, our assistive listening headsets have a 3.5mm headphone jack to connect to those devices.

In order to ensure the highest quality experience for all guests, you may not enter a movie after it has started. We’d love to see you up to 30 minutes early. Running late? No worries, we will happily exchange your ticket for a different showtime or a raincheck to a future show.

sessionAttributes.name: All Ages
sessionAttributes.description: For all ages shows, we welcome babies and kids of all ages. The no talking rules are relaxed, since kids will be kids. But other than that, you can expect the full Alamo experience.

sessionAttributes.name: Kid Friendly
sessionAttributes.description: Grab the fam and let the fun begin! Our Kid Friendly screenings include pre-show activity sheets and crayons, a relaxed noise policy, and kids menus. Ages 3+ welcome with a parent or guardian.

sessionAttributes.name: Sensory Friendly
sessionAttributes.description: Our all-inclusive screenings welcome babies, infants, nursing moms, and guests with Autism and other sensory needs. Sound will be quieter. Theater will be a little less dark. Chatter, walking around, and babies being babies are A-OK.

formats.title: 35mm
formats.headline: Film print projected using film projectors.
formats.description: The industry standard for theatrical film releases prior to digital cinema. Film print projected using film projectors.

agePolicies.name: !!DO NOT USE!! All Ages
agePolicies.description: All ages will be allowed at all screenings of this show.

agePolicies.name: Rated G
agePolicies.description: All minors under the age of 18 must be accompanied by an adult. Children ages 6+ admitted. Children 5 and under (including infants) are ONLY admitted during specifically designated "All Ages" and "Family Friendly" screenings.

agePolicies.description: All minors under the age of 18 must be accompanied by an adult. Children ages 6+ admitted. Children 5 and under (including infants) are ONLY admitted during specifically designated "All Ages" and "Family Friendly" screenings.

agePolicies.description: All minors under the age of 18 must be accompanied by an adult. Children ages 6+ admitted. Children 5 and under (including infants) are ONLY admitted during specifically designated "All Ages" and "Family Friendly" screenings.
